metadata.description: Batch import of 55 Roman historical figures (509 BCE - 476 CE) with verified Wikidata Q-IDs. Focus on figures with extensive media portrayals in films, TV shows, books, and games. Includes emperors, generals, senators, writers, philosophers, and key political figures from both the Roman Republic and Roman Empire periods.

figures.name: Gaius Julius Caesar
figures.title: Roman General and Dictator
figures.description: Roman general and statesman who played a critical role in the demise of the Roman Republic and rise of the Roman Empire. Subject of countless films, TV shows, and games including HBO's Rome, Asterix series, and Civilization games.

figures.name: Augustus
figures.title: First Roman Emperor
figures.description: First Roman Emperor who transformed Rome from a Republic into an Empire. Born Gaius Octavius, adopted by Julius Caesar. Featured in HBO's Rome, I Claudius, and numerous historical dramas.

figures.name: Marcus Tullius Cicero
figures.title: Roman Statesman and Orator
figures.description: Roman statesman, lawyer, scholar, philosopher, and orator who attempted to uphold republican principles during the final civil wars. His writings remain influential in Western philosophy and rhetoric.

figures.name: Marcus Junius Brutus
figures.title: Roman Senator
figures.description: Roman senator and most famous of Julius Caesar's assassins. Central character in Shakespeare's Julius Caesar and numerous film adaptations including the 1953 MGM film.

figures.name: Cleopatra VII
figures.title: Queen of Egypt
figures.description: Last active pharaoh of Ptolemaic Egypt, closely connected to Roman politics through relationships with Julius Caesar and Mark Antony. Subject of numerous films including the 1963 epic starring Elizabeth Taylor.

figures.name: Marcus Antonius (Mark Antony)
figures.title: Roman Politician and General
figures.description: Roman general and politician, member of the Second Triumvirate who formed alliance with Cleopatra. Featured prominently in HBO's Rome and Shakespeare's Julius Caesar and Antony and Cleopatra.

figures.name: Tiberius
figures.title: Second Roman Emperor
figures.description: Second Roman Emperor (14-37 CE), stepson of Augustus. Featured in I, Claudius (BBC series) and Ben-Hur. Known for his competent but increasingly tyrannical rule.

figures.name: Caligula
figures.title: Third Roman Emperor
figures.description: Third Roman Emperor (37-41 CE) known for his cruelty, extravagance, and alleged insanity. Subject of the infamous 1979 film Caligula and featured in I, Claudius and Netflix's Roman Empire series.

figures.name: Claudius
figures.title: Fourth Roman Emperor
figures.description: Fourth Roman Emperor (41-54 CE), subject of the acclaimed BBC series I, Claudius based on Robert Graves' novels. Expanded the Empire and reformed bureaucracy despite physical disabilities.

figures.name: Nero
figures.title: Fifth Roman Emperor
figures.description: Fifth and last Julio-Claudian emperor (54-68 CE), infamous for persecution of Christians and alleged fiddling during Great Fire of Rome. Featured in Quo Vadis (1951), Netflix's Roman Empire, and numerous other works.

figures.name: Vespasian
figures.title: Founder of Flavian Dynasty
figures.description: Ninth Roman Emperor (69-79 CE), founder of the Flavian dynasty, ended Year of the Four Emperors. Portrayed by Anthony Hopkins in Peacock's Those About to Die (2024). Began construction of the Colosseum.

figures.name: Titus
figures.title: Tenth Roman Emperor
figures.description: Tenth Roman Emperor (79-81 CE), son of Vespasian. Commanded Roman forces during Siege of Jerusalem in 70 CE. Completed the Colosseum. Featured in various historical dramas about the Jewish-Roman wars.

figures.name: Domitian
figures.title: Eleventh Roman Emperor
figures.description: Eleventh Roman Emperor (81-96 CE), younger son of Vespasian. Known for autocratic rule and building programs. Last emperor of the Flavian dynasty.

figures.name: Trajan
figures.title: Optimus Princeps
figures.description: Thirteenth Roman Emperor (98-117 CE), second of the Five Good Emperors. Expanded empire to its greatest territorial extent. Trajan's Column commemorates his Dacian Wars and remains standing in Rome.

figures.name: Hadrian
figures.title: Builder Emperor
figures.description: Fourteenth Roman Emperor (117-138 CE), third of Five Good Emperors. Built Hadrian's Wall in Britain and Pantheon in Rome. Featured in Memoirs of Hadrian by Marguerite Yourcenar.

figures.name: Antoninus Pius
figures.title: Fourth of Five Good Emperors
figures.description: Fifteenth Roman Emperor (138-161 CE), known for peaceful and prosperous reign. Built the Antonine Wall in Scotland. Longest reign of the Nerva-Antonine dynasty.

figures.name: Marcus Aurelius
figures.title: Philosopher Emperor
figures.description: Sixteenth Roman Emperor (161-180 CE), last of the Five Good Emperors. Stoic philosopher, author of Meditations. Featured in Gladiator (2000) portrayed by Richard Harris. His reign marked by Marcomannic Wars.

figures.name: Commodus
figures.title: Gladiator Emperor
figures.description: Seventeenth Roman Emperor (177-192 CE), son of Marcus Aurelius. Known for fighting as gladiator and erratic rule. Main antagonist in Gladiator (2000) played by Joaquin Phoenix. Featured in Netflix's Roman Empire series.

figures.name: Septimius Severus
figures.title: Founder of Severan Dynasty
figures.description: Twenty-first Roman Emperor (193-211 CE), founder of Severan dynasty, first African-born emperor. Strengthened military, expanded empire eastward. Featured in historical documentaries about Rome's African emperors.

figures.name: Caracalla
figures.title: Emperor of Constitutio Antoniniana
figures.description: Twenty-second Roman Emperor (198-217 CE), son of Septimius Severus. Granted Roman citizenship to all free inhabitants of empire. Built the Baths of Caracalla. Known for brutal and paranoid rule.

figures.name: Diocletian
figures.title: Reformer Emperor
figures.description: Fifty-first Roman Emperor (284-305 CE), established Tetrarchy system dividing empire into four regions. Major administrative and military reforms stabilized empire after Crisis of Third Century. Only emperor to voluntarily abdicate.

figures.name: Constantine I (Constantine the Great)
figures.title: First Christian Emperor
figures.description: Fifty-seventh Roman Emperor (306-337 CE), first to convert to Christianity. Founded Constantinople as new capital. Issued Edict of Milan legalizing Christianity. Featured in numerous historical films and Constantine TV series.

figures.name: Julian (Julian the Apostate)
figures.title: The Apostate Emperor
figures.description: Roman Emperor (361-363 CE), nephew of Constantine. Attempted to restore traditional Roman paganism after Christian reign. Philosopher-emperor who wrote against Christianity. Subject of Gore Vidal's novel Julian.

figures.name: Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus (Pompey the Great)
figures.title: Triumvir and General
figures.description: Roman military and political leader, member of First Triumvirate with Caesar and Crassus. Defeated by Caesar in civil war. Featured in HBO's Rome, Asterix comics, and numerous historical novels.

figures.name: Marcus Licinius Crassus
figures.title: Richest Man in Rome
figures.description: Roman general and politician, member of First Triumvirate. Defeated Spartacus revolt. Known as wealthiest man in Rome. Killed in disastrous Battle of Carrhae against Parthians. Featured in Spartacus films and series.

figures.name: Spartacus
figures.title: Gladiator Rebel Leader
figures.description: Thracian gladiator who led major slave uprising (Third Servile War) against Roman Republic. Subject of 1960 Kubrick film starring Kirk Douglas and Starz TV series (2010-2013). Symbol of resistance against oppression.

figures.name: Hannibal Barca
figures.title: Carthaginian General
figures.description: Carthaginian general who led army including war elephants across Alps to invade Italy during Second Punic War. Rome's greatest enemy. Featured in numerous films, games (Total War, Civilization), and historical documentaries.

figures.name: Publius Cornelius Scipio Africanus
figures.title: Conqueror of Hannibal
figures.description: Roman general who defeated Hannibal at Battle of Zama, ending Second Punic War. Earned cognomen Africanus. One of Rome's greatest military commanders. Featured in Total War games and historical novels.

figures.name: Marcus Porcius Cato (Cato the Younger)
figures.title: Republican Stoic
figures.description: Roman senator and Stoic philosopher, defender of republican constitution against Caesar. Famous for opposition to Julius Caesar and dramatic suicide at Utica. Inspiration for Cato's Letters and American founding fathers.

figures.name: Gaius Cassius Longinus
figures.title: Caesar's Assassin
figures.description: Roman senator and general, main instigator of conspiracy to assassinate Julius Caesar. Featured prominently in Shakespeare's Julius Caesar and HBO's Rome. Committed suicide after Battle of Philippi.

figures.name: Marcus Aemilius Lepidus
figures.title: Third Triumvir
figures.description: Roman politician and general, member of Second Triumvirate with Octavian and Mark Antony. Eventually stripped of power by Octavian. Featured in HBO's Rome and Shakespeare's Julius Caesar.

figures.name: Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa
figures.title: Augustus's Right Hand
figures.description: Roman general, architect, and statesman, closest friend and son-in-law of Augustus. Commanded fleet at Battle of Actium. Built original Pantheon. Featured in HBO's Rome as key supporter of Octavian.

figures.name: Publius Vergilius Maro (Virgil)
figures.title: Greatest Roman Poet
figures.description: Roman poet, author of the Aeneid (founding myth of Rome), Georgics, and Eclogues. Dante's guide through Inferno and Purgatorio in Divine Comedy. Foundational figure in Western literature.

figures.name: Publius Ovidius Naso (Ovid)
figures.title: Poet of Metamorphoses
figures.description: Roman poet known for Metamorphoses (mythological epic), Ars Amatoria, and Fasti. Exiled by Augustus to Tomis on Black Sea. Major influence on Western art and literature, particularly Renaissance.

figures.name: Quintus Horatius Flaccus (Horace)
figures.title: Lyric Poet
figures.description: Roman lyric poet during Augustus's reign. Known for Odes, Satires, Epistles, and Ars Poetica. Coined carpe diem. Patron was Maecenas. Major influence on Western poetry.

figures.name: Titus Livius (Livy)
figures.title: Historian of Rome
figures.description: Roman historian, author of Ab Urbe Condita (History of Rome from its founding to 9 BCE). Primary source for early Roman history. Influenced Renaissance historians and political thought.

figures.name: Publius Cornelius Tacitus
figures.title: Greatest Roman Historian
figures.description: Roman senator and historian, author of Annals, Histories, Germania, and Agricola. Primary source for Julio-Claudian and Flavian dynasties. Influenced Enlightenment political thought.

figures.name: Gaius Suetonius Tranquillus (Suetonius)
figures.title: Imperial Biographer
figures.description: Roman historian, author of The Twelve Caesars (biographies from Julius Caesar to Domitian). Primary source for early imperial period. Influenced biographical writing through modern era.

figures.name: Lucius Annaeus Seneca (Seneca the Younger)
figures.title: Stoic Philosopher
figures.description: Roman Stoic philosopher, statesman, and dramatist. Tutor and advisor to Emperor Nero. Author of philosophical essays, letters, and tragedies. Forced to commit suicide by Nero. Major influence on Renaissance drama and Stoic revival.

figures.name: Gaius Plinius Secundus (Pliny the Elder)
figures.title: Natural Historian
figures.description: Roman author, naturalist, and naval commander. Author of Naturalis Historia (encyclopedia of natural world). Died during eruption of Mount Vesuvius while attempting rescue. Primary source for ancient science.

figures.name: Gaius Plinius Caecilius Secundus (Pliny the Younger)
figures.title: Letter Writer and Governor
figures.description: Roman lawyer, author, and magistrate. Nephew of Pliny the Elder. Famous for letters describing Vesuvius eruption, correspondence with Trajan, and early Christian persecution. Primary source for daily Roman life.

figures.name: Lucius Apuleius
figures.title: Novelist and Philosopher
figures.description: Roman-Berber writer and Platonist philosopher. Author of The Golden Ass (Metamorphoses), only ancient Roman novel to survive in full. Influenced picaresque novel tradition.

figures.name: Gaius Valerius Catullus (Catullus)
figures.title: Neoteric Poet
figures.description: Roman poet of late Republic, known for passionate love poetry to Lesbia (Clodia Metelli). Influenced later love poetry including Shakespeare's sonnets. Perfected hendecasyllabic meter.

figures.name: Petronius Arbiter
figures.title: Arbiter of Elegance
figures.description: Roman courtier and author during Nero's reign. Attributed author of Satyricon, satirical novel featuring Trimalchio's feast. Forced to commit suicide by Nero. Influenced picaresque literature.

figures.name: Decimus Iunius Iuvenalis (Juvenal)
figures.title: Satirist
figures.description: Roman poet, author of Satires criticizing Roman society under early empire. Coined panem et circenses (bread and circuses). Influenced Western satire including Swift and Johnson.

figures.name: Marcus Vitruvius Pollio (Vitruvius)
figures.title: Architect and Engineer
figures.description: Roman architect and engineer, author of De architectura (only surviving ancient architectural treatise). Described Vitruvian Man proportions used by Leonardo da Vinci. Influenced Renaissance architecture.

figures.name: Gaius Maecenas
figures.title: Patron of the Arts
figures.description: Roman diplomat and political advisor to Augustus. Patron to Virgil, Horace, and other poets. Name became synonymous with patronage of arts. Featured in HBO's Rome.

figures.name: Lucius Cornelius Sulla Felix
figures.title: Dictator and Reformer
figures.description: Roman general and statesman who became dictator. First to march on Rome with army. Conducted proscriptions against enemies. Constitutional reforms strengthened Senate. Featured in Colleen McCullough's Masters of Rome series.

figures.name: Gaius Marius
figures.title: Third Founder of Rome
figures.description: Roman general and statesman elected consul seven times. Reformed Roman legions (Marian Reforms). Defeated invading Germanic tribes. Mentor and rival of Sulla. Featured in Masters of Rome series.

figures.name: Lucius Sergius Catilina (Catiline)
figures.title: Conspirator
figures.description: Roman senator who attempted coup against Republic (Catiline Conspiracy). Exposed by Cicero in famous Catiline Orations. Killed in battle against senatorial forces. Subject of Sallust's historical monograph.

figures.name: Tiberius Gracchus
figures.title: Populist Reformer
figures.description: Roman tribune who attempted land reforms to help poor citizens. Assassinated by senatorial mob. His death marked beginning of violent phase of Roman politics. Featured in works on Roman social conflict.

figures.name: Gaius Gracchus
figures.title: Populist Reformer
figures.description: Roman tribune and brother of Tiberius, continued reform agenda with grain law and judicial reforms. Killed in political violence. Brothers known as Gracchi, symbols of popular reform movement.

figures.name: Publius Clodius Pulcher
figures.title: Populist Tribune
figures.description: Roman politician known for populist legislation and street violence. Enemy of Cicero whom he exiled. Murdered by rival Milo's gang on Appian Way. Subject of Cicero's Pro Milone speech.

figures.name: Clodia Metelli (Lesbia)
figures.title: Aristocrat and Muse
figures.description: Roman aristocrat, sister of Clodius, believed to be Lesbia of Catullus's love poetry. Defended against poisoning charge by Cicero in Pro Caelio. Emblematic of elite Roman women's freedom and influence.

figures.name: Agrippina the Younger
figures.title: Mother of Nero
figures.description: Roman empress, great-granddaughter of Augustus, mother of Nero. Married uncle Claudius, secured throne for Nero. Murdered by Nero's order. Featured in I, Claudius and Agrippina opera by Handel.

figures.name: Livia Drusilla
figures.title: First Roman Empress
figures.description: Wife of Augustus, most powerful woman in early Empire. Accused (possibly falsely) of poisoning rivals. Promoted son Tiberius as heir. Featured prominently in I, Claudius as scheming matriarch.

figures.name: Messalina (Valeria Messalina)
figures.title: Third Wife of Claudius
figures.description: Roman empress, third wife of Claudius, notorious in ancient sources for promiscuity and plots. Executed by Claudius's order after attempting bigamous marriage. Featured in I, Claudius and symbol of sexual excess.

figures.name: Poppaea Sabina
figures.title: Second Wife of Nero
figures.description: Roman empress, second wife of Nero. Ancient sources allege Nero killed her by kicking while pregnant. Allegedly instrumental in Nero's murder of Agrippina. Featured in Monteverdi's L'incoronazione di Poppea opera.

figures.name: Zenobia
figures.title: Queen of Palmyra
figures.description: Queen of Palmyrene Empire who challenged Rome during Crisis of Third Century. Conquered Roman territories in East. Defeated and captured by Aurelian. Symbol of resistance and powerful female ruler. Subject of historical fiction.
